comments.commentBody: I remember reading about Manifest Destiny, and I am convinced that American Exceptionalism is the same thing.

I have not forgotten that Sister Sarah believes the East Coast is not "real America" so I don't understand why she is coming here.   I wish she and the god-awful Rolling Thunder would go somewhere else this Memorial Day weekend.

Does this woman ever pay for anything?
Beside setting up yet another shell company to paint patriotic slogans on a bus, she is asking her followers to finance her tour by making donations.
She does not state specifically what actions she will take, beyond giving speeches and making personal appearances, she is not really doing anything to help improve this country.
This just another free trip at someone else's expense.
No wonder she bought a house in Arizona. She hardly spend any time in Alaska anymore. There are many from her home state who feels she has abandoned them since John McCain gave her first taste of the good life on the main land.

To tell the truth, I'm a bit irritated that her handlers may be planning to insinuate an association with the Rolling Thunder Rally in DC . The first Rolling Thunder began in 1987 as a demonstration to bring awareness to the plight of prisoners of war (POW) and to those missing in action (MIA). "Rolling Thunder originated when four Vietnam Veterans, exercising the First Amendment "Right to Petition and Assemble", organized the first group of 2500 motorcycles to ride through the streets of Washington, DC. This first Rolling Thunder run was made in an attempt to petition the government to take responsibility for the soldiers that were abandoned after the Vietnam War ended." http://www.rollingthundermotorcyclerally.com/

I wore a POW braclet for three or four years when I was in the Air Force. (It was the only jewelry other than a watch or wedding ring that we were allowed to wear while in uniform.) I doubt seriously that Sarah Palin was invited by the organizers to be there. (That would be a good fact check item.) As a Vietnam Veteran, this political ploy offends me. I see this as the worst sort of political opportunism. I don't care if her bus travels around as long as she doesn't attempt to insert herself where she isn't invited.

Rock bands tour. Opera companies tour. Ballet companies tour. Theater groups tour. Sports teams goes on the road
Does Sarah Palin sing, dance ,act play a musical instrument or shoot hoops? Tour indeed!

I was so pleased to read this astute appreciation of Mary Chesnut's diaries by Catherine Clinton, whom I know to be an outstanding historian and thinker.
Francie Parker Newcomb

Scott Fitzgerald, the Republican Senate majority leader, criticized Judge Sumi’s decision.

“There’s still a much larger separation-of-powers issue: whether one Madison judge can stand in the way of the other two democratically elected branches of government,” he said in a statement. “The Supreme Court is going to have the ultimate ruling.”

Can anyone spot the logical contradiction? I guess the way this works is that the judicial branch is to be disparaged as activist until the ruling goes your way. When it goes your way (if you're a Republican) the judges are upholding the Constitution. Heads you lose, tails I win.

So Scott Fitzgerald thinks that the Courts has no right to serve as a check and balance on the exercise of power by the legislative branch?  Perhaps he should re-take 7th grade civics.  Oh the hypocrisy!

To Kneedragon in AZ. Thank your union for the decent wages and benefits you earn. Try relying on the good hearts of your employers like most do and I'm sure you'ed change your tune. Unions are the last stand against unrestricted exploitation of the working people of America. Even union haters have benefitted from the workers rights gained by union activism, shame they don't know it. Five day work week, eight hour day, where do you think these and many other standards came from? The uninformed are easy to mislead. As for companies hiring qualified people, tell that to the thousands of qualified Americans who have lost their jobs thanks to H1B visa workers imported to lower the pay standards of all workers.
Thank goodness for the Founding Fathers!  This is exactly the kind of situation in which the system of checks and balances is called into action.

WHAT THE SCIENTISTS SAY:
Climate change believers had let the science do your thinking for them, they also let the scientists do their “speaking” for them. This is what they said on behalf of the climate change believers for 25 years of warnings:

* That world faces a stark choice between: “strong action on climate change and oblivion.”” -United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon warned and still warns.
*"This is an historic step forward in the world's efforts to combat a truly global threat."
Kofi Annan, Secretary-General of the United Nations
*"The Greenland ice sheet is likely to be eliminated [within 50 years] unless much more substantial reductions in emissions are made than those envisaged [and will] probably be irreversible, this side of a new ice age."
Jonathan Gregory, climatologist at the University of Reading
*"Climate change is the most severe problem that we are facing today, more serious even than the threat of terrorism." - David King, UK government chief scientific adviser
*"The absolutely best case scenario - which in my opinion is unrealistic - with the minimum expected climate change... we end up with an estimate of 9% [of all species] facing extinction." -
Chris Thomas, ecologist at the University of Leeds
*"An awful lot of people are living only a foot above high water and do not know it." - Jim Titus, US Environmental Protection Agency

One of the ways Christians try to explain away natural catastrophes is to assert that Satan rules the earth, and it is he who causes the atmospheric and geological catastrophes. Those who survive believe "God had a plan for me." The Christian God in this scenario is apparently, as Woody Allen had him, "an underachiever."

So who is the Devil? Well, maybe he's Exxon, and maybe he's spreading his dirty lucre among Republicans and some Congressional ConservaDems. Our Congress members are merely pawns, after all, to the God of Mammon, unable to resist the Temptation, as Jesus did in his 40 days and 40 nights in the wild.

Isn't it swell how even a non-believer can find answers to life's important questions in the Bible?

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com
The medical-industrial establishment games the medicare system mercilessly. More procedures and tests = more income. And that's what's driving this into the ground.

I always love scanning through the NYTimes and discovering amazing gems like this. You had to feel some pride that of ALL the compositions this Nono guy (yes, I am aware he is known as a brilliant composer, but he's still a Nono guy) picked yours to critique. It's quite possible that his critique was derived from projecting what he thought others would think of his work. It never fails that our work will reflect our life and our life will reflect our work. Obviously from reading these posts (and your essay), your life is a composition of one great work. BTW - I just listened to a piece of "Everything Must Go" and it is quite divine. Brilliant pieces on your web site.

I haven't seen the LA series, but Jamie Oliver's Virginia series was fascinating. A bit suspect, as it made it appear it was just him when there must have been a staff. And how did he (they) not know his offerings would not fit the criteria? Clearly produced and editied for drama. But still...you saw that the goals of the school food service was to deliver a lunch and breakfast that was really cheap and low labor, and that the kids with no knowledge or experience with food would happily eat, and that fulfilled the letter of the federal or state requirements. The cafeteria might serve reheated deep fried chicken fingers for breakfast and lunch, and what did the kids get for dinner at home? Yup, probably microwaved deep fried chicken fingers.

I attended a week long summer seminar at UVA two years ago. They had consolidated their food service for all the dorms in one big new building, a fifteen minute walk from the farthest dorm (way to go, UVA, how much money did that save you?). The food was what would appeal to those same kids when they were a bit older. I had brought powdered milk and healthy cereal and instant coffee, and ate it in my room for breakfast after trying the cafeteria, which was free with the seminar. You could put together a sort of decent dinner by picking out stuff like brocolli from the salad bar and something from the vegetarian section etc. Other than that - fat and carbs and deep fried protein. They had chicken ONCE in the week, breaded and deep fried. The scrambled eggs at breakfast were only available with so much salt that salt was the predominate flavor. Thomas Jefferson would be appalled, and not just about the lack of fine vintage French wine. Fortunately, the seminar provided really nice box lunches from somewhere else!

If your state was hit by a flood, fire, or tornado this spring, more likely than not, your Congressional Representative or Senator voted against the existence of climate change and against studying weather and climate. They also support  budgets that de-fund or force major cuts to FEMA and the National Weather Service. Perhaps you or a loved one is alive or in a safe location today due to the work of these two agencies. Please take this into consideration when you vote in 2012.
I found this movie funny at some parts like when the air marshall scene but others were just way to long and boring. This movie was made by the same people who made super bad and knocked up.

comments.commentTitle: I wish I had been as stoned as the acters portrayel of dopers
comments.commentBody:
I saw Jerusalem last night and was almost one of the many walkouts but I was really desparate for something to do.
Mr. Brantley must not have never been stoned in college because Jerusalem is just about a bunch of lowlifes making up silly stories while they are stoned (and we all know how much fun that is to watch). Just as it was in college, the folks that were stoned were enjoying themselves alot more than the people that were watching them.
This is not just an assumption on my part, dope is prevalent in the play and we are meant to believe that the characters are loaded on booze or grass.
I really tried to make something out of it but Rooster's stories were hardly that creative. Mythic, Mr. Brantley? I'm sorry, but I prefer my mythic characters with some color, character and a touch of dignity. My roomate provided much better alliteration in his verbal description of the Benjamin Britten War Requiem while totally blasted.
There is no doubt that Mr. Rylance gives a great performance of a drunk drug pusher but do you really want to watch that for 3 hours.
The blessing here is that, as another reader said, this play will never be done again. It's just plain very bad writing.

comments.commentBody: Broadway producers:  are you listening?

If you're looking for last minute hotels near the concert venue, you can always check out:

http://www.usaticketing.com/bethel-woods-center-for-the-arts/

Pop in the dates, and you'll find the closest hotels available.

comments.commentTitle: Bin House:  the couture textile house of Asia
comments.commentBody: We now live in Brooklyn but during our 17 years of living in asia  we were able to discover classic treasures. Bin HOuse is at the top of this list. Virtually every day in New York I wear a bin scarf or sarong (worn as a very generous scarf). They are equally popular with my hipster 20 something daughter as with my proper mother in-law. Far more interesting than an Hermes design, they are coveted by sophisticated Japanese ladies. EVERY time I wear one of these treasures I get huge compliments. They have been sold in Barneys and Bergdorfs. A Bin HOuse scarf transcends cultures and ethnicities with it's complex weaving and innovative designs.

Everywhere I go, people express alarm that Medicare is being messed with. These people don't care whether it's done by Dems or RePubs, they will vote the responsible parties out and do everything in their power to convince others to do the same. So will I.

comments.commentTitle: Sweet boutique hotel with perfect location in Saint Germain des Pres
comments.commentBody:
I love the left bank of the Seine and always try to stay there when I come to Paris. I’ve tried several hotels in the latin quarter and saint germain area… with varying degrees of success! The Odeon Hotel is definitely the best, with a charming vintage decoration in good Parisian style. Everything looked so romantic to me (even the walk up to our room with exposed stone walls and wooden beams has delighted us)…This boutique hotel is very clean and cosy, not huge and not too small. It is located in the trendy 6th arrondissement, surrounded by café and restaurants, just a stone’s throw from the Seine river, the Luxembourg Gardens and Saint Germain des prés! Can’t wait to go there and roam the crooked romantic streets of Latin Quarter again!
http://www.hotelsgrandparis.com/odeon-hotel-paris.html

comments.commentTitle: Merrion Hotel is not the Merrion Inn
comments.commentBody: The map depicts the Merrion Inn, which is not the Merrion Hotel.   The Merrion Hotel is near St Stephen's Green.
